00034 #ifndef BAYESIAN_INFORMATION_CRITERION_H
00035 #define BAYESIAN_INFORMATION_CRITERION_H
00036 ///
00037 /// @file bic.h
00038 /// @brief Template function implementations of the Bayesian Information Criterion.
00039 ///
00040 /// The Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) is a criterion for model selection
00041 /// that balances a maximum likelihood estimator and a parameter count.  This
00042 /// implementation is designed for clustering algorithms, in particular K-means and
00043 /// K-medoids clustering algorithms where we expect clusters with  spherical gaussian
00044 /// distributions.  
00045 ///
00046 /// Here, we want to test whether a clustering's centroids or medoids are good predictors
00047 /// of the points in a data set, so these are our parameters, and we try to find the best
00048 /// clustering without too many clusters.  For more on this technique and the approach
00049 /// we've based this implementation on, see this paper:
00050 /// @par
00051 /// Dan Pelleg and Andrew Moore.  <a href="http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dpelleg/download/xmeans.pdf">
00052 /// <b>X-Means: Extending K-Means with Efficient Estimation of the Number of Clusters</b></a>.
00053 /// <i>Proceedings of the Seventeenth International Conference on Machine Learning</i>, 
00054 /// San Francisco, CA. June 29-July 2, 2000.  pp 727-734.
00055 /// 
00056 
00057 #include <stdint.h>
00058 #include <numeric>
00059 #include <iostream>
00060 #include <cmath>
00061 #include <vector>
00062 #include "dissimilarity.h"
00063 #include "partition.h"
00064 
00065 namespace cluster {
00066   
00067   ///
00068   /// Directly computes the BIC from a partition object based on the cluster centroids
00069   /// and the number of clusters.
00070   /// 
00071   /// @param[in] p         A partition object describing the clustering to be evaluated.
00072   /// @param[in] distance  A distance function callable on two \em indices from the partition p.
00073   /// @param[in] M         Dimensionality parameter -- degrees of freedom in the input dataset.
00074   ///
00075   /// @return A valid BIC score based on the input parameters.  Higher numbers indicate better fit.
00076   /// 
00077   template <typename D>
00078   double bic(const partition& p, D distance, size_t M) {
00079     double R = p.size();
00080     size_t k = p.num_clusters();
00081 
00082     // calculate variance.
00083     double s2 = total_squared_dissimilarity(p, distance) / (R - k);
00084     double s  = sqrt(s2);
00085     double sM = pow(s, (double)M);
00086 
00087     // compute sizes of the clusters in the partition.
00088     size_t sizes[k];
00089     for (size_t i=0; i < k; i++) {
00090       sizes[i] = p.size(i);
00091     }
00092 
00093     // compute BIC from point probabilities
00094     double root2pi = sqrt(2 * M_PI);
00095     double lD = 0;
00096     for (size_t i=0; i < p.size(); i++) {
00097       double d  = distance(i, p.medoid_ids[p.cluster_ids[i]]);
00098       double Ri = sizes[p.cluster_ids[i]];
00099       lD += 
00100         + log(1.0 / (root2pi * sM))
00101         - (1 / (2 * s2)) * d * d
00102         + log(Ri / R);
00103     }
00104 
00105     const size_t pj = (k-1) + M*k + 1;   // free parameter count
00106     return lD - pj/2 * log((double)R);
00107   }
00108 
00109 
00110   ///
00111   /// This version of the BIC assumes some precomputed information.  This is useful for
00112   /// parallel implementations, where it is more efficient to compute some global sums as a 
00113   /// reduction rather than aggregating a full partition to one process.  Here,
00114   /// we assume that the sizes of the distributed clusters as well as the total squared intra-cluster
00115   /// dissimilarity (between each object and its medoid) is known.
00116   /// 
00117   ///    @param[in] k               Number of clusters in the clustering.  Same as k from k-means or k-medoids.
00118   ///    @param[in] cluster_sizes   Start of range of k sizes.  
00119   ///                               <code>*cluster_sizes .. *(cluster_sizes + k)</code> should be the
00120   ///                               sizes of clusters 1 to k
00121   ///    @param[in] sum2_dissim     Sum of squared dissimilarities of each object w.r.t. its nearest medoid.
00122   ///    @param[in] dimensionality  Dimensionality of clustered data.  e.g., 2 for 2-dimensional points.
00123   ///
00124   template <typename SizeIterator, typename DissimIterator>
00125   double bic(size_t k, SizeIterator cluster_sizes, DissimIterator sum2_dissim, size_t dimensionality) {
00126     // figure out total size of data set and put it in R.
00127     const double R      = std::accumulate(cluster_sizes, cluster_sizes + k, 0);
00128     const double M      = dimensionality;    // Shorthand for model dimensionality
00129     const double logR   = log(R);
00130     const double log2pi = log(2 * M_PI);
00131     const double pj     = (k-1) + M*k + 1;   // free parameter count
00132     const double s2     = std::accumulate(sum2_dissim, sum2_dissim + k, 0.0) / (R - k);
00133 
00134     // apply criterion formula from xmeans paper.
00135     double criterion = 0;
00136     for (size_t i=0; i < k; i++) {
00137       const double Rn = *(cluster_sizes + i);
00138       criterion += 
00139         - (Rn * log2pi) / 2.0
00140         - (Rn * M * log(s2)) / 2.0 
00141         - (Rn - 1) / 2.0 
00142         + Rn * log(Rn) 
00143         - Rn * logR;
00144     }
00145     criterion -= (pj/2.0 * logR);
00146     
00147     return criterion;
00148   }
00149 
00150 };
00151 
00152 #endif // BAYESIAN_INFORMATION_CRITERION_H
